lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's use destructuring to simplify props usage.

Make sure to pick { followed by author, and then text, }, {, author, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these allows for destructuring props directly in the function parameter?

const MyComponent = ({prop1, prop2}) => {}const MyComponent = ([prop1, prop2]) => {}const MyComponent = (props.prop1, props.prop2) => {}const MyComponent = props => {}

const MyComponent = ({prop1, prop2}) => {}.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use destructuring with default values in case properties are not present.

Make sure to pick { followed by model and then =, "Unknown", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the result of using a ternary operator like this in the App component?

Status: OfflineStatus: ActiveStatus: UndefinedStatus: Null

Status: Offline.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that displays a default "Basic Package" for the plan property if no value for the plan property is passed.

Make sure to type plan.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Given the React component below, what will be displayed when it's rendered without any props?

Hello, Friend!Hello, User!Hello, Developer!Goodbye, Friend!

Hello, Friend!.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Given the following JSX code, which statement is true?

Using car as a key could cause issues if duplicate values existKeys are not required, as React handles it internallyindex would be a less appropriate choice than car for the keyThe code will throw an error without additional attributes

Using car as a key could cause issues if duplicate values exist.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of book titles.

Make sure to type books.map.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that maps over a list of video game titles to display them.

Make sure to type games.map.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be displayed when this component is rendered?

Gotham, Metropolis, Star CityNo cities displayedGotham and MetropolisAn error message

Gotham, Metropolis, Star City.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is a key benefit of using controlled components?

They allow React to handle dataThey eliminate the need for user inputThey require no event handling for updatesThey automatically prevent form submission

They allow React to handle data.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Extract props using destructuring.

Make sure to pick alias, followed by alias.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Destructure the passed property name.

Make sure to type name.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the Profile component inside a React fragment.

Make sure to pick renderedLevel followed by <> and then renderedLevel, </>.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Given the following code, what would be printed if the level property is missing?

Level: NoviceLevel: 0Level: MasterLevel: Undefined

Level: Novice.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set default values for the properties "Good Morning" for greeting and "Everyone" for audience.

Make sure to pick = followed by "Good Morning" and then =, "Everyone".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why might you use object destructuring for default values in a component?

To simplify code and provide clear defaults for propertiesTo convert components to classesTo make all properties optionalTo hide certain properties from the output

To simplify code and provide clear defaults for properties.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following practices should be avoided when setting keys in a React list?

Using the element as key when elements can be duplicatsUsing unique static identifiers as keysProviding consistent unique keys for each itemEnsuring keys are set for all elements in the list

Using the element as key when elements can be duplicats.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a JSX list rendering favorite songs where song names are used as unique keys.

Make sure to pick songs followed by . and then map, song, song, song.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Construct a simple React component that lists fruit names and uses index as the key value.

Make sure to pick fruits followed by . and then map, fruit, index, index, fruit.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
How does React identify each element in a list?

Using the key propertyUsing the id attributeUsing the class attributeUsing the style attribute

Using the key property.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to create a controlled input to capture a movie title.

Make sure to pick setMovieTitle.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Develop a simple character counter that displays the number of characters inputted by the user.

Make sure to pick event followed by . and then target, ., value, ., length.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you handle an event in a React component?

By passing a function as a prop with an event handlerBy calling a method directly inside JSXUsing the alert function inside the render methodUsing this.setEvent method

By passing a function as a prop with an event handler.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that echoes back whatever the user types with exclamation marks.

Make sure to pick handleChange followed by event and then setEcho, event, handleChange, echo.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Change the input field's text color dynamically based on the input length being even or odd.

Make sure to pick input followed by setInput and then input, .length.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Update the state value based on the textarea input length.

Make sure to pick setLength followed by event and then ., target, ., value, ., length.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to add an event handler.

Make sure to pick handleChange followed by onChange= and then {, handleChange, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you correctly track the input of a textarea element in React?

By setting the value and updating with onChangeBy adding a default attributeBy removing value and onChangeBy setting its type as 'controlled'

By setting the value and updating with onChange.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the outcome if we try to modify the state directly in React, like stateVar.push("newItem"), without calling a setter function?

React won't recognize the state changeIt will always update the UIAn error will be thrownState will reset to default

React won't recognize the state change.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a button to clear the array.

Make sure to pick clearCharacters followed by setCharacters and then [], button, onClick, clearCharacters.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is it necessary to assign a new array using the spread operator instead of modifying the existing array when working with state?

Because React's state needs a new reference to trigger re-renderIt prevents callback hellArrays only allow read operations in ReactThe existing array will be automatically replaced by the new one

Because React's state needs a new reference to trigger re-render.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a shopping list component where each time you press the button, you add a new item.

Make sure to pick setList followed by ( and then [, ., ., ., list, ,, "Beer", ], ), ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following best describes the useState hook in controlled components?

It initializes and updates the component's stateIt renders the component's UI only onceIt resets the input field to a default valueIt connects the component to a database

It initializes and updates the component's state.
